text: Number 548, Roderick Jenkins versus John Julien McKeithen et al.
Yes.
Very well.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

But I take it in the long run, as far as filing of charges is concerned that the action of the Commission is only a recommendation and they can't themselves effectively file a -- they can file a complaint with the law enforcement officer I suppose like any citizen can but they can officially launch a criminal action.
The case is not in the technical sense of the word.
You mean the law enforcement officer still has to make his decisions whether actually to file a charge than is it to the criminal proceeding?
That's correct Your Honor.
Well, the Commission has arrived that it's opinion of the matter I take it but it certainly doesn't bind the law enforcement official I take it.
I'm sure it doesn't bind the law enforcement official technically.
It doesn't even bind him to file a charge.

It doesn't even bind him to file a charge but I'm sure that in the ordinary affairs of public government where that same district attorney by virtue of the provisions of the statute himself is impressed cooperatively as a member of this Commission.
Does Louisiana use a grand jury?
Yes, sir, Louisiana does.
I suppose there are some crimes that require an indictment by a grand jury?
Murder is one of them.
Well, I suppose then that the grand jury might reject indicting someone even though the Commission had recommended it.
I'm sure that's a possibility, Your Honor.
Do you suggest that as a practical matter, no prosecutor could afford to reject one of these recommendations in so far as filing the complaints?
It would be my judgment but it would be hazardous position for him to assume.
Mr. Chief Justice --
Mr. Stewart.
Yes, sir.
My interpretation to (Inaudible)
A legal adjudication.
But they can't (Inaudible).
No sir.
(Inaudible)
They have no authority to accuse anyone just as in the Civil Rights Commission.
